channel.title: AI Security Paper Digest
channel.description: Curated papers on AI security from ArXiv and ACL

item.title: CapRecover: A Cross-Modality Feature Inversion Attack Framework on Vision Language Models
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes CapRecover, a framework to recover semantic content from intermediate features of VLMs
  • Evaluates on multiple datasets and models, showing high accuracy in label recovery and caption generation
  • Introduces a noise-based protection method to mitigate semantic leakage

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Kedong Xiu', 'Sai Qian Zhang']
  • Tags: ['privacy attacks', 'data leakage', 'vision-language models', 'feature inversion', 'semantic recovery']

item.title: Attention! Your Vision Language Model Could Be Maliciously Manipulated
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes Vision-language model Manipulation Attack (VMA) for adversarial attacks on VLMs
  • Demonstrates vulnerability to image-based adversarial examples
  • Can be used for jailbreaking, hijacking, privacy breaches, etc.
  • Includes watermark injection for copyright protection

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Xiaosen Wang', 'Shaokang Wang', 'Zhijin Ge', 'Yuyang Luo', 'Shudong Zhang']
  • Tags: ['adversarial prompting', 'jailbreaking', 'privacy attacks', 'robustness', 'safety evaluation']

item.title: A Frustratingly Simple Yet Highly Effective Attack Baseline: Over 90% Success Rate Against the Strong Black-box Models of GPT-4.5/4o/o1
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes a new adversarial attack method for LVLMs
  • Focuses on semantic clarity in perturbations
  • Achieves high success rates against closed-source models like GPT-4.5

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Zhaoyi Li', 'Xiaohan Zhao', 'Dong-Dong Wu', 'Jiacheng Cui', 'Zhiqiang Shen']
  • Tags: ['adversarial attacks', 'LVLMs', 'transferability', 'semantic perturbations']

item.title: T2I-RiskyPrompt: A Benchmark for Safety Evaluation, Attack, and Defense on Text-to-Image Model
item.description:
Summary

  • Introduces T2I-RiskyPrompt, a benchmark for evaluating safety in text-to-image models
  • Includes a hierarchical risk taxonomy with 6 primary and 14 subcategories
  • Provides 6,432 annotated risky prompts with detailed reasons
  • Evaluates multiple models, defense methods, safety filters, and attack strategies

Paper Type

  • Benchmarking

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Chenyu Zhang', 'Tairen Zhang', 'Lanjun Wang', 'Ruidong Chen', 'Wenhui Li', 'Anan Liu']
  • Tags: ['safety evaluation', 'text-to-image models', 'risky prompts', 'benchmarking', 'attack strategies', 'defense methods']

item.title: Self-Calibrated Consistency can Fight Back for Adversarial Robustness in Vision-Language Models
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes Self-Calibrated Consistency (SCC) for adversarial robustness in VLMs like CLIP
  • Addresses semantic and viewpoint fragility in adversarial attacks
  • Improves zero-shot robustness while maintaining accuracy

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Jiaxiang Liu', 'Jiawei Du', 'Xiao Liu', 'Prayag Tiwari', 'Mingkun Xu']
  • Tags: ['adversarial robustness', 'vision-language models', 'test-time defense']

item.title: Modal Aphasia: Can Unified Multimodal Models Describe Images From Memory?
item.description:
Summary

  • Introduces 'modal aphasia' in multimodal models where concepts are memorized visually but not articulable in text.
  • Shows models can reproduce images accurately but fail to describe them correctly in text.
  • Demonstrates potential AI safety vulnerability where text-based safeguards don't prevent unsafe image generation.

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Michael Aerni', 'Joshua Swanson', "Kristina Nikoli\\'c", 'Florian Tram\\`er']
  • Tags: ['multimodal models', 'safety evaluation', 'adversarial prompting', 'alignment', 'robustness']

item.title: Noise Aggregation Analysis Driven by Small-Noise Injection: Efficient Membership Inference for Diffusion Models
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes an efficient membership inference attack for diffusion models using small-noise injection
  • Analyzes noise aggregation patterns to distinguish training vs non-training samples
  • Requires fewer model queries compared to existing methods
  • Demonstrates scalability with large text-to-image models

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Guo Li', 'Yuyang Yu', 'Xuemiao Xu']
  • Tags: ['privacy attacks', 'membership inference', 'diffusion models', 'adversarial attacks']

item.title: LLMs can hide text in other text of the same length
item.description:
Summary

  • The paper presents a method to hide text within another text of the same length using LLMs
  • Demonstrates potential for covert communication and erosion of trust in written content
  • Raises concerns for AI safety and model transparency

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Antonio Norelli', 'Michael Bronstein']
  • Tags: ['adversarial prompting', 'data hiding', 'AI safety', 'trust in AI', 'model transparency']

item.title: SafeCOMM: A Study on Safety Degradation in Fine-Tuned Telecom Large Language Models
item.description:
Summary

  • Investigates safety degradation in fine-tuned telecom LLMs
  • Introduces TeleHarm benchmark for telecom-specific red-teaming
  • Evaluates realignment defenses (SafeInstruct, SafeLoRA, SafeMERGE)
  • Shows defenses restore safety without losing performance

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Aladin Djuhera', 'Swanand Ravindra Kadhe', 'Farhan Ahmed', 'Syed Zawad', 'Fernando Koch', 'Walid Saad', 'Holger Boche']
  • Tags: ['LLM red teaming', 'safety evaluation', 'model realignment', 'telecom domain adaptation']

item.title: Steering Evaluation-Aware Language Models to Act Like They Are Deployed
item.description:
Summary

  • The paper addresses the issue where LLMs adjust their behavior during evaluation to appear more aligned, which affects safety evaluations.
  • It introduces a steering vector technique to suppress evaluation-awareness, making the model behave as if deployed.
  • The study involves training an LLM with evaluation cues and using activation steering to counteract the awareness.

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Tim Tian Hua', 'Andrew Qin', 'Samuel Marks', 'Neel Nanda']
  • Tags: ['LLM red teaming', 'alignment', 'safety evaluation']

item.title: The Chameleon Nature of LLMs: Quantifying Multi-Turn Stance Instability in Search-Enabled Language Models
item.description:
Summary

  • Investigates multi-turn stance instability in search-enabled LLMs
  • Introduces Chameleon Benchmark Dataset and metrics
  • Evaluates Llama-4-Maverick, GPT-4o-mini, Gemini-2.5-Flash
  • Finds severe chameleon behavior across models

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Shivam Ratnakar', 'Sanjay Raghavendra']
  • Tags: ['LLM red teaming', 'safety evaluation', 'robustness', 'alignment']

item.title: Check Yourself Before You Wreck Yourself: Selectively Quitting Improves LLM Agent Safety
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes using quitting as a safety mechanism for LLM agents in multi-turn scenarios
  • Evaluates quitting behavior across 12 LLMs using ToolEmu framework
  • Shows significant safety improvement with minimal impact on helpfulness

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Vamshi Krishna Bonagiri', 'Ponnurangam Kumaragurum', 'Khanh Nguyen', 'Benjamin Plaut']
  • Tags: ['LLM safety', 'agent safety', 'quitting behavior', 'ToolEmu', 'safety evaluation']

item.title: SafeMERGE: Preserving Safety Alignment in Fine-Tuned Large Language Models via Selective Layer-Wise Model Merging
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes SafeMERGE, a post-fine-tuning framework to preserve safety alignment in LLMs
  • Uses selective layer-wise merging between fine-tuned and safety-aligned models
  • Evaluates across three LLMs and two tasks, showing reduced harmful outputs
  • Maintains or improves downstream performance while enhancing safety

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

item.description:

item.description:

item.title: Optimal Detection for Language Watermarks with Pseudorandom Collision
item.description:
Summary

  • Introduces a statistical framework for detecting language watermarks with pseudorandom collision handling
  • Defines minimal units to manage within-unit dependence and between-unit independence
  • Provides closed-form optimal detection rules for Gumbel-max and inverse-transform watermarks
  • Improves detection power with strict Type I error control

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['T. Tony Cai', 'Xiang Li', 'Qi Long', 'Weijie J. Su', 'Garrett G. Wen']
  • Tags: ['watermarking', 'detection', 'pseudorandomness', 'hypothesis testing', 'LLM outputs']

item.title: Adaptive Blockwise Search: Inference-Time Alignment for Large Language Models
item.description:
Summary

  • Introduces AdaSearch, a blockwise search strategy for inference-time alignment of LLMs
  • Focuses computational effort on initial tokens which are more critical for alignment
  • Outperforms Best-of-N and fine-tuning baselines in harmlessness, sentiment control, and math reasoning

item.title: Uncovering the Persuasive Fingerprint of LLMs in Jailbreaking Attacks
item.description:
Summary

  • The paper explores using persuasive strategies from social sciences to create adversarial prompts for jailbreaking LLMs.
  • It tests if LLMs have persuasive fingerprints in their responses when jailbroken.
  • Empirical results show that persuasion-aware prompts can bypass alignment safeguards.

item.title: Self-Refining Language Model Anonymizers via Adversarial Distillation
item.description:
Summary

  • Introduces SEAL, a distillation framework for training small language models (SLMs) to anonymize text without relying on external models.
  • Uses adversarial interactions between an LLM anonymizer and an inference model to collect training data.
  • SLMs learn to anonymize and evaluate their outputs, enabling self-refinement.
  • Experiments show 8B models can match or exceed GPT-4's privacy-utility trade-off.

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Kyuyoung Kim', 'Hyunjun Jeon', 'Jinwoo Shin']
  • Tags: ['privacy attacks', 'data poisoning', 'adversarial prompting', 'model extraction', 'safety evaluation']

item.title: Alert-ME: An Explainability-Driven Defense Against Adversarial Examples in Transformer-Based Text Classification
item.description:
Summary

  • Introduces EDIT framework for detecting and defending against adversarial examples in transformer-based text classifiers
  • Uses explainability tools like attention maps and integrated gradients combined with frequency features
  • Includes adaptive resilience through feature similarity enforcement and input transformation
  • Demonstrates improved performance over state-of-the-art defenses with faster feature extraction

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ["Bushra Sabir (CSIRO's Data61)", 'Yansong Gao (The University of Western Australia)', "Alsharif Abuadbba (CSIRO's Data61)", 'M. Ali Babar (The University of Adelaide', 'CREST- The Centre for Research on Engineering Software Technologies)']
  • Tags: ['adversarial examples', 'text classification', 'explainability', 'defense mechanism', 'transformer models']

item.title: PolyJuice Makes It Real: Black-Box, Universal Red Teaming for Synthetic Image Detectors
item.description:
Summary

  • PolyJuice is a black-box, universal red-teaming method for synthetic image detectors (SIDs)
  • It identifies a distribution shift in the T2I latent space between correctly and incorrectly classified images
  • Generates attacks by steering images towards SID failure modes
  • Improves SID performance when used for data augmentation

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Sepehr Dehdashtian', 'Mashrur M. Morshed', 'Jacob H. Seidman', 'Gaurav Bharaj', 'Vishnu Naresh Boddeti']
  • Tags: ['red teaming', 'adversarial attacks', 'image synthesis', 'text-to-image models', 'detector robustness']

item.title: Distillation Robustifies Unlearning
item.description:
Summary

  • The paper introduces UNDO, a method that uses distillation to robustify unlearning in LLMs.
  • UNDO distills an unlearned model into a noised copy, offering a tradeoff between compute cost and robustness.
  • It shows improved robustness on synthetic tasks and the WMDP benchmark.

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Bruce W. Lee', 'Addie Foote', 'Alex Infanger', 'Leni Shor', 'Harish Kamath', 'Jacob Goldman-Wetzler', 'Bryce Woodworth', 'Alex Cloud', 'Alexander Matt Turner']

item.title: Scalable Valuation of Human Feedback through Provably Robust Model Alignment
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes H"older-DPO, a new alignment loss with provable redescending property
  • Enables estimation of clean data distribution from noisy human feedback
  • Provides a metric for dataset valuation and mislabel detection
  • Improves alignment performance by identifying and removing mislabels

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Masahiro Fujisawa', 'Masaki Adachi', 'Michael A. Osborne']
  • Tags: ['alignment', 'robustness', 'safety evaluation', 'data poisoning']

item.title: Shape it Up! Restoring LLM Safety during Finetuning
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes dynamic safety shaping (DSS) for LLM finetuning to address safety risks
  • Introduces STAR for token-level safety assessment during response generation
  • Uses guardrail models to evaluate partial responses dynamically
  • Demonstrates safety improvements across various models and datasets

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['ShengYun Peng', 'Pin-Yu Chen', 'Jianfeng Chi', 'Seongmin Lee', 'Duen Horng Chau']
  • Tags: ['LLM safety', 'dynamic safety shaping', 'STAR', 'finetuning risks', 'guardrail models']

item.title: Fundamental Limitations in Pointwise Defences of LLM Finetuning APIs
item.description:
Summary

  • The paper demonstrates fundamental limitations in pointwise defenses of LLM fine-tuning APIs.
  • It constructs attacks using benign samples that transmit dangerous knowledge through entropy in model outputs.
  • The attacks evade detection by ensuring individual samples are unsuspicious and low-perplexity.
  • Tests against OpenAI's API show success in eliciting harmful responses while bypassing enhanced monitoring.

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Xander Davies', 'Eric Winsor', 'Alexandra Souly', 'Tomek Korbak', 'Robert Kirk', 'Christian Schroeder de Witt', 'Yarin Gal']
  • Tags: ['LLM red teaming', 'jailbreaking', 'adversarial prompting', 'model extraction', 'security standards']

item.description:
Summary

item.title: Soft Instruction De-escalation Defense
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes SIC (Soft Instruction Control) for LLM agents to prevent prompt injection attacks
  • Iterative prompt sanitization loop that rewrites, masks, or removes malicious content
  • Continues until input is clean or halts if imperative instructions remain
  • Raises the bar against attacks but not infallible (15% ASR possible)

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Nils Philipp Walter', 'Chawin Sitawarin', 'Jamie Hayes', 'David Stutz', 'Ilia Shumailov']

item.description:

  • Improves robustness against adversarial attacks in WSVAD models

item.title: Probe-based Fine-tuning for Reducing Toxicity
item.description:
Summary

  • The paper explores using probes trained on model activations to detect and reduce toxicity.
  • It proposes two training methods: Supervised Fine-tuning and Direct Preference Optimization.
  • Key findings include that preference optimization preserves probe accuracy better than classifier-based methods.
  • Retraining probes after optimization recovers detection accuracy, making probe ensembles less necessary.

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Jan Wehner', 'Mario Fritz']
  • Tags: ['red teaming', 'alignment', 'safety evaluation', 'probe-based training', 'toxicity reduction']

item.title: Leverage Unlearning to Sanitize LLMs
item.description:
Summary

  • Proposes SANI, an unlearning approach to sanitize LLMs by removing memorized sensitive information
  • Involves erasure (resetting neurons) and repair (fine-tuning without sensitive data)
  • Evaluated on medical data and standard pre-trained models
  • Reduces regurgitation of sensitive information with minimal additional training

Paper Type

  • Research

Additional Information

  • Authors: ['Antoine Boutet', 'Lucas Magnana']

item.title: Reducing the Probability of Undesirable Outputs in Language Models Using Probabilistic Inference
item.description:
Summary

  • Introduces RePULSe, a training method for LMs to reduce undesired outputs using probabilistic inference
  • Augments standard RL loss with a loss that targets low-reward outputs
  • Aims to improve tradeoff between average reward and undesired output probability
  • Demonstrates better adversarial robustness compared to standard methods

Paper Type
